title: Is There Really a Christian Tradition in the West? An Exploration of Occultism and the Occidental Character.
first_phrase: In the previous text, the author discusses the limited spread of Christianity in certain regions and the dominance of Islam in others, leading to the minority of Christians globally. The author now moves to the topic of the alleged Christian character of Western tradition and questions the presuppositions of such a claim. The author contests the notion that the West has been entirely Christianized, that Christian tradition held the sacred deposit of knowledge, and that there wasn't any continuity or derivation from pagan mysteries and initiation. Furthermore, the author challenges the idea of the existence of an esoteric Christian tradition in the West.

last_phrase: In conclusion, the assertion that the Western initiatic tradition must have a Christian character is not conclusive. The negation of the existence of a non-Christian center or tradition in the modern West may not necessarily mean that it does not exist but could be deliberately hidden. Therefore, caution is required when making this distinction, especially when dealing with esoteric and mysterious matters with peculiar and contingent conditions of the past and present.
